title: Ordinance Would Change The Way Pets Are Left Outside
text:
Ordinance Would Change The Way Pets Are Left Outside By Bryant Somerville Sunday October 11, 2015 8:51 PM UPDATED: Sunday October 11, 2015 9:33 PM LANCASTER, Ohio - 
Everywhere she goes, Linda Morgan has a shadow. 
She calls her seven-and-a-half-year-old lab mix, Taylor, her baby. 
She's a dog lover who is excited about potential new rules for dog owners. 
"It just breaks my heart to see these animals treated the way they are," she said. 
Lancaster City Councilwoman, Becky Tener is sponsoring a new ordinance that is scheduled to be voted on, Monday. 
"I get calls about animals that are left out," she said. "And, they don't have proper shelter." 
If approved, the ordinance would change the way pets are left outside. Owners would not be allowed to use tethers that could cause entanglement or injury. Also, water bowls must be mounted or weighed down. Crates for dogs would also have changes. Pet owners could only use enclosed structures with one door and it must be insulated and kept at least two inches from the ground to avoid moisture seeping through the bottom. 
"I think we're just taking it too far," Lancaster City Councilman, Michael Fracassa said. 
Fracassa wants to protect animals, but says the ordinance, which does not differentiate between outside and indoor pets, is a burden on tax payers. 
"I think it's too restrictive to animal owners," he said. 
But Fairfield Area Humane Society Executive Director, Corey Schoonover, says if you've seen horror stories like he has of animals being left out, Fracassa might think differently. 
"When you see that on a daily basis, I don't think you would think it's too restrictive," Schoonover said. 
Dog owners, like Morgan, say what's being asked is not too much. 
"These are the bare minimums that these animals deserve," she said.
